original.definition: cause to do preliminary exercises so as to stretch the muscles

sememes.reasoning: The verb describes causing a transition in a person's physical state from being unprepared to a state of readiness for activity.

participants.reasoning: The 'Somebody' who initiates and causes the warming up, as specified by the verb frame.
The 'somebody' whose physical state is changed to being warmed up.

sememes.reasoning: The change in physical state is accomplished through the performance of exercises, as stated in the definition 'preliminary exercises'.

participants.reasoning: The 'somebody' who is being warmed up is also the one who performs the preliminary exercises.

sememes.reasoning: The explicit goal of the preliminary exercises is 'to stretch the muscles,' which is a key part of the verb's definition.

participants.reasoning: The muscles are the body parts that are intended to be stretched through the activity.

Evidentiality.reasoning: The act of causing someone to warm up is typically a directly observable event.

Mood.reasoning: The verb's core meaning is declarative, stating an action.

Modality.reasoning: The presence of a volitional agent ('Somebody') in the frame implies the action is driven by their will and intention.

Polarity.reasoning: The act of warming up is inherently neutral; its positive or negative sentiment depends on context.

Volitionality.reasoning: The frame 'Somebody ----s somebody' clearly indicates a volitional agent performing the causative action.

Confidence.reasoning: The verb describes a definite occurrence of causing someone to warm up.

Iterativity.reasoning: The lexeme describes a single, complete event of causing someone to be warmed up, even if the underlying exercises are repetitive.

candidates.description: (Middle Ages) one of the four fluids in the body whose balance was believed to determine your emotional and physical state (gloss match)
a datum about some physical state that is presented to a user by a meter or similar instrument (gloss match)
one of the minimum number of parameters needed to describe the state of a physical system (gloss match)

(philosophy) the philosophical theory that formal (logical or mathematical) statements have no meaning but that its symbols (regarded as physical entities) exhibit a form that has useful applications (gloss match)
the entire body of physically fit civilians eligible by law for military service; ; --United States Constitution (gloss match)
United States comic actor in silent films; he used physical danger as a source of comedy (1893-1971) (gloss match)
a definite stable energy that a physical system can have; used especially of the state of electrons in atoms or molecules (gloss match)
the state of being an isomer; the complex of chemical and physical phenomena characteristic of isomers (gloss match)
the condition of living or the state of being alive (gloss match)
the state of being physically constrained (gloss match)
(physical chemistry) a distinct state of matter in a system; matter that is identical in chemical composition and physical state and separated from other material by the phase boundary (gloss match)

(physical chemistry) a fourth state of matter distinct from solid or liquid or gas and present in stars and fusion reactors; a gas becomes a plasma when it is heated until the atoms lose all their electrons, leaving a highly electrified collection of nuclei and free electrons (gloss match)
